case_count_quote: This case describes a woman in her 50s who presented with recurrent lower respiratory tract infections.
patient_age_quote: A female patient in her 50s was referred to the specialist respiratory outpatient clinic
patient_sex_quote: This case describes a woman in her 50s
presenting_symptoms: Recurrent lower respiratory tract infections, chronic cough productive of green sputum for 4 months, longstanding dyspnoea on walking up hills, generalized malaise
presenting_symptoms_quote: She reported a chronic cough for 4 months, productive of moderate volumes of green sputum. There were no triggers and no diurnal variation. She reported longstanding dyspnoea on walking up hills only. She had generalised malaise but denied haemoptysis, weight loss and night sweats.
diagnostic_method: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgical (VATS) guided wedge resection with biopsies from right upper, middle and lower lobe
diagnostic_method_quote: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgical (VATS) guided wedge resection was performed with biopsies taken from the right upper, middle and lower lobe.
imaging_findings: Multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules with upper lobe predominance, 6mm left upper lobe nodule and two 5mm nodules in right upper lobe, background fibrotic ILD with subpleural changes affecting lung apices and right lower lobe, several small calcified granulomata bilaterally
imaging_findings_quote: High-resolution CT of the chest revealed background fibrotic ILD with predominantly subpleural changes, affecting the lung apices and right lower lobe. One 6 mm left upper lobe nodule was identified and two 5 mm nodules in the right upper lobe. There was no mediastinal adenopathy but several small, calcified granulomata were noted bilaterally
histopathology: Small intraparenchymal minute nodules of bland epithelioid cells without malignancy, with tobacco-related changes including emphysema, small airway disease with bronchiectasis, peribronchial metaplasia, inflammation and respiratory bronchiolitis
histopathology_quote: Histopathology revealed small intraparenchymal minute nodules of bland epithelioid cells without any evidence of malignancy. In addition, there were tobacco-related changes of emphysema, small airway disease with bronchiectasis, peribronchial metaplasia, peribronchial inflammation and respiratory bronchiolitis.
immunohistochemistry: Positive for CD56 and progesterone receptor, weakly positive for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and smooth muscle actin (SMA). Negative for TTF-1, napsin A, chromogranin, HMB45, S100 and desmin.
immunohistochemistry_quote: The nodules stained positive for neural cell adhesion molecule (CD56) and progesterone receptor, and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and smooth muscle actin (SMA) were weakly positive. Staining was negative for TTF-1, napsin A, chromogranin, HMB45, S100 and desmin.
treatment_quote: There are no specific treatments or recommendations available on how best to approach treatment in the case of DPM.
outcome: Stable symptoms with ongoing productive cough, stable spirometry over 4 years with DLCO drop from 76% to 67.6%, stable nodules on 2-year follow-up CT
outcome_quote: Her symptoms remain stable with an ongoing productive cough. Spirometry has remained stable over a 4-year period with a drop in DLCO from 76% to 67.6% predicted value. Using the Fleischner Society pulmonary nodule guidelines, repeat CT thorax at a 2-year interval showed stable appearances of previously described lung nodules.
comorbidities: Ex-smoker, history of livestock farm work
comorbidities_quote: She was an ex-smoker and had worked on a livestock farm for many years.
filename: Healy et al. - 2023 - Diffuse pulmonary meningotheliomatosis a rare cause of multiple pulmonary nodules.pdf
extraction_notes: The case is well-documented with clear clinical details, diagnostic workup, and follow-up information. Most data points are explicitly stated in the text with direct quotes available.

case_count_quote: A 63 year old female presented for incidentally discovered pulmonary nodules.
presenting_symptoms: No respiratory complaints including dyspnea, cough or sputum production
presenting_symptoms_quote: she denied any respiratory complaints including dyspnea, cough or sputum production
diagnostic_method_quote: transbronchial biopsies revealed many meningothelial like bodies confirming the diagnosis of Diffuse Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis
imaging_findings: Innumerable and diffusely distributed nodules up to 4mm in a military type pattern, no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy
imaging_findings_quote: CT scan of the chest with contrast showed innumerable and diffusely distributed nodules up to 4mm in a military type pattern. There was no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy
histopathology_quote: transbronchial biopsies revealed many meningothelial like bodies
outcome: No abnormalities suggestive of underlying malignancy on PET/CT
outcome_quote: Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography (PET/CT) scan of our patient did not reveal abnormalities suggestive of underlying malignancy
comorbidities: 10 pack-year smoking history and occupational chemical fume exposure
comorbidities_quote: Medical, social and family history was remarkable for a 10 pack-year smoking history and occupational chemical fume exposure, working in a compounding pharmacy
filename: Gleason - 2016 - Meningotheliomatosis A Rare Cause of Diffuse Miliary Pattern Pulmonary Opacities.pdf
extraction_notes: Most information is clearly stated in the text. The military/miliary distinction in imaging findings is preserved as written in the source text. No specific treatment is mentioned in the text so that field is omitted. Immunohistochemistry results are not mentioned.

case_count_quote: Of the 25 cases identified 2 were male (8%), and 23 were female (92%).
patient_age_quote: Ages ranged from 37 to 73 with a median age of 59.5 years at diagnosis.
patient_sex_quote: Of the 25 cases identified 2 were male (8%), and 23 were female (92%).
presenting_symptoms: 60% asymptomatic with incidental findings, 32% with unexplained respiratory complaints
presenting_symptoms_quote: 15 (60%) were asymptomatic and imaging abnormalities were discovered incidentally. 8 (32%) had unexplained respiratory complaints.
diagnostic_method: Surgical lung biopsy and transbronchial biopsy
diagnostic_method_quote: 3 (12%) were diagnosed by transbronchial biopsy while the remainder had surgical lung biopsies.
imaging_findings_quote: Diffuse pulmonary meningotheliomatosis should be considered in all patients with diffuse bilateral pulmonary nodules on HRCT.
histopathology: Meningothelial-like nodules containing small epithelioid cell collections within normal pulmonary parenchyma
histopathology_quote: These meningothelial-like nodules are classically encountered as benign solitary pulmonary nodules containing small epithelioid cell collections nestled within normal pulmonary parenchyma.
immunohistochemistry: Positive: Vimentin, EMA; Negative: Cytokeratin AE1/AE3, synaptophysin, CAM5.2 low molecular weight keratin, muscle specific actin, s-100 protein, CD34
immunohistochemistry_quote: ( - ) Cytokeratin AE1/AE3, synaptophysin, CAM5.2 low molecular weight keratin, muscle specific actin, s-100 protein, CD34 (+) Vimentin, EMA
comorbidities: 44% had history of or active malignancy
comorbidities_quote: 11 (44%) had history of or active malignancy.
filename: Gleason et al. - 2017 - Diffuse pulmonary meningotheliomatosis A literature review of a rare diffuse parenchymal lung disea 1.pdf
extraction_notes: Data extracted primarily from systematic review results section. Strong confidence in demographic and diagnostic information. No specific treatment or outcome data provided in text.

case_count_quote: Literature describing DPM is very limited, with only 25 cases documented through 2016.
patient_age_quote: A 45-year-old female with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia
patient_sex_quote: A 45-year-old female with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia
presenting_symptoms_quote: The patient refers to occasional bouts of dyspnea with no temporal association of years of evolution for which she uses budesonide/formoterol as needed.
diagnostic_method: open biopsy of the right lung
diagnostic_method_quote: An open biopsy of the right lung was performed and pathological examination revealed meningothelial nodules
imaging_findings: innumerable bilateral thin-walled pulmonary cysts with thickened interlobular septa
imaging_findings_quote: A high-resolution chest CT scan revealed innumerable bilateral thin-walled pulmonary cysts with thickened interlobular septa, suggestive of lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM).
histopathology: meningothelial nodules with cavitating diffuse pulmonary meningotheliomatosis
histopathology_quote: pathological examination revealed meningothelial nodules, with histologic findings supporting the diagnosis of cavitating diffuse pulmonary meningotheliomatosis.
treatment_quote: The patient refers to occasional bouts of dyspnea with no temporal association of years of evolution for which she uses budesonide/formoterol as needed.
comorbidities_quote: A 45-year-old female with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and hyperlipidemia
filename: Torrech Santos et al. - 2023 - Diffuse Cavitating Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis A Rare and Elusive Pathology.pdf
extraction_notes: The case is well-documented with clear patient demographics, symptoms, diagnostic methods, and findings. No specific outcome was reported beyond the initial diagnosis and management. The patient's clinical course and long-term outcomes were not mentioned.

case_count_quote: We present a case of a 57-year-old woman
patient_age_quote: We present a case of a 57-year-old woman
patient_sex_quote: We present a case of a 57-year-old woman
presenting_symptoms_quote: a 57-year-old woman with a history of chronic cough
diagnostic_method: Wedge resections from right upper and lower lobes
diagnostic_method_quote: Wedge resections from the right upper and right lower lobes were obtained
imaging_findings_quote: CT imaging findings of bilateral multiple ground-glass nodules
histopathology: discrete areas with variable interstitial expansion of the stroma with ovoid/spindle cells, collagen, elastosis, and mild chronic inflammatory cells, in a somewhat perivascular pattern. Some areas were also cystic, with background of emphysematous change and focal foreign body giant cell reaction
histopathology_quote: discrete areas with variable interstitial expansion of the stroma with ovoid/spindle cells, collagen, elastosis, and mild chronic inflammatory cells, in a somewhat perivascular pattern. Some areas were also cystic. This appeared in a background of emphysematous change and focal foreign body giant cell reaction to non-polarizable material.
immunohistochemistry: diffusely positive for vimentin, EMA, and PR; CD163 highlighted increased cells that were S100 and CD1a negative; negative for desmin, SMM, HMB-45, HHV8, pan-CK, chromogranin, and multiplex SOX10-MART1
immunohistochemistry_quote: Immunohistochemical stains were diffusely positive for vimentin, EMA , and PR, and CD163 highlighted increased cells that were S100 and CD1a negative. Additionally, the ovoid/spindle cells were negative for desmin, SMM, HMB-45, HHV8, pan-CK, chromogranin, and multiplex SOX10-MART1.
filename: Forsythe et al. - 2022 - Diffuse Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis A Case Report 1.pdf
extraction_notes: This appears to be a clear case report of diffuse pulmonary meningotheliomatosis (DPM) with well-documented clinical, imaging, and pathological findings. The outcome is not explicitly stated in the provided text.

case_count_quote: A 63-years-old male patient was admitted to our hospital
patient_age_quote: A 63-years-old male patient was admitted to our hospital
patient_sex_quote: A 63-years-old male patient was admitted to our hospital
presenting_symptoms_quote: A 63-years-old male patient was admitted to our hospital with cough and mild exertional dyspnea
diagnostic_method: surgical wedge resection after nondiagnostic bronchoscopy
diagnostic_method_quote: Bronchoscopy was nondiagnostic which led to a diagnostic surgical procedure. The patient underwent diagnostic right lower lobe and middle lobe wedge resections.
imaging_findings: bilaterally multiple, uniform, thin-walled cysts ranging between 0.5 and 2.5 cm in diameter, diffusely distributing from apex to basis of the lung; micronodules smaller than 1 mm
imaging_findings_quote: Thorax HRCT scan revealed bilaterally multiple, uniform, thin-walled cysts ranging between 0.5 and 2.5 cm in diameter, diffusely distributing from apex to basis of the lung suggesting lymphangioleiomyomatosis radiologically . [...] When HRCT findings were reviewed, micronodules smaller than 1 mm were identified.
histopathology_quote: Histopathological examination revealed diffuse meningotheliomatosis unexpectedly.
treatment_quote: Although the patient only received symptomatic treatment
outcome: stable - no changes in CT findings over 3 years
outcome_quote: there were no changes in thorax CT findings through the three years follow up
filename: Aksel et al. - 2019 - An Unusual Case of Diffuse Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis Accompanying with Cystic Lung Disease.pdf
extraction_notes: All key information was clearly stated in the text. The only uncertainty might be around the complete details of the symptomatic treatment, which were not specified.

case_count_quote: We describe a case of a 58-year-old female
patient_age_quote: We describe a case of a 58-year-old female
patient_sex_quote: We describe a case of a 58-year-old female
presenting_symptoms: dyspnoea on exertion and persistent non-productive coughing for 3 months, dyspepsia and nausea
presenting_symptoms_quote: presented with complaints of dyspnoea on exertion and persistent non-productive coughing for 3 months. She also complained of dyspepsia and nausea.
diagnostic_method_quote: Thoracoscopic lung biopsy was performed, with histology revealing pulmonary parenchyma with preserved lung architecture... The immunohistochemical profile found the nodules to be positive for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and progesterone receptor (PR)
imaging_findings: diffuse micronodular infiltrates in a miliary pattern bilaterally
imaging_findings_quote: Chest X-ray and chest computed tomography (CT) images, however, revealed diffuse micronodular infiltrates in a miliary pattern bilaterally
histopathology: Numerous small stellate-shaped nodular lesions throughout lung tissue, comprising islands of epithelioid cells with appearance of arachnoidal cells, showing eosinophilic cytoplasm with bland, uniform and ovoid nuclei, some featuring pseudoinclusions
histopathology_quote: Numerous small stellate-shaped nodular lesions were distributed throughout the lung tissue... On higher magnification, the nodules comprised islands of epithelioid cells, with the appearance of arachnoidal cells. The cells showed eosinophilic cytoplasm, accompanied by bland, uniform and ovoid nuclei, some featuring pseudoinclusions.
immunohistochemistry: positive for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and progesterone receptor (PR)
immunohistochemistry_quote: The immunohistochemical profile found the nodules to be positive for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and progesterone receptor (PR)
treatment_quote: being on treatment with lamotrigine and donepezil
comorbidities: frontal lobe syndrome secondary to previous traumatic brain injury, reflux oesophagitis
comorbidities_quote: being on treatment with lamotrigine and donepezil after a diagnosis of frontal lobe syndrome secondary to previous traumatic brain injury... gastroscopy performed as part of the diagnostic investigations for persistent cough found her to have reflux oesophagitis
filename: Maasdorp et al. - 2020 - Diffuse pulmonary meningotheliomatosis â€“ A Case Report.pdf
